posts.name:
Ruffin Mitchener
Ruffin Mitchener
posts.content:
Last year, I launched a private slack community for female founders and women in VC (+ active angels). Why? A Yale University study found that gender bias in venture capital is undisputed.

Finding that investors who have experienced a poor outcome from a woman-led startup shy away from other women founders—but benefitting from successes of women founders doesn’t lead them to invest more.

All-women founding teams have never secured more than 3% of venture capital funding. The point of our community is to bring together female founders and funders and provide a space for knowledge-sharing, networking, and check-writing!

I'm proud to report in 2024, we had our first pre-seed deal sourced and closed via the community. More on that soon 

I've seen the power of community, and know we can make progress by coming together.

If you're interested in joining, drop your email in the comments (or DM me), so I can share more information

comments.commentText: YES Ruffin Mitchener keep doing this great work, it matters :)
Regina Bernal, M.A. thank you !!!
Congrats Ruffin this is AWESOME!
Kat Weaver thank you for your support in 2024!! Your workshop was a huge hit

posts.name:
Keith LAU
Keith LAU
posts.content:
I spoke with a job seeker friend who applied for 240 jobs on LinkedIn. He only selected job postings that were no more than 7 days old.

Surprisingly, 218 of his applications were not viewed by the recruiters who posted them.

The remaining 22 applications were also a disappointment, with 80% receiving an automatic rejection within a few minutes of applying.

He managed to get 3 interviews:

- An automated online chat from which he never heard back
- A phone screening with a junior recruiter who wasn't prepared for the interview
- An interview with a panel of 3 people. He made a good first impression and got to the second round, only to be ghosted after that.

Stop wasting people's time and fix the hiring process once and for all.

Ok?
- Your Recruitment Adviser

comments.commentText: Need help with job search? Visit my profile…
Keith LAU please.....

I am curious if each application was tailored for each job description or did the job seeker mass apply using the exact same resume across all 240 jobs? In my experience both as a job seeker and hiring manager the success rate in far higher when the resume is written specifically for the desired position. I estimate per 100 applications I read less than 10% of applicants are doing this, I rarely consider the other 90% because I don't have the time to read between the lines to figure out how/if past experiences align with role. Quality over quantity always!

posts.name:
Matt Sayers
Matt Sayers
posts.content:
To whomever works at LinkedIn that this applies to. PLEASE start cracking down on some of these fake jobs being posted... Maybe start with a more thorough screening of jobs posted on the recruiting platform with "Easy Apply"....then we'll go from there.

It diminishes the platform for professional use as it relates to job advertisement and engagement.

To the rest of us, the Easy Apply is great... but do some homework on the organization you are applying to before you give them all your info. Takes about 2 minutes of research. Then when you see their advertisements again you just scroll on by.

posts.name:
Eli Weber
Eli Weber
posts.content:
Work ON your business, not IN your business.

This concept comes up all the time.

I see business owners doing everything themselves: bookkeeping, customer service, even cooking in their own restaurants.

I always tell people:
 If your hour is worth $500, but you’re spending it on tasks worth $20/hour, you’re losing money.

I also tell my employees with leadership responsibilities the same thing:
The less you actually “do,” the better you’ll perform.

Why? Because when you’re not caught up in busywork, you have time to:
️ Think of new ideas.
️ Focus on strategy.
️ Build a long-term vision.

This is why most businesses, like restaurants, struggle to scale. The owner is often behind the counter or in the kitchen, working in the business instead of on it. No one’s focusing on marketing, customer service, or the bigger picture.

Delegation isn’t a luxury—it’s a necessity for a business that wants to grow.

I'm curious, what things have you delegated that have helped you scale your business?

comments.commentText:
Love this!! It’s so true.. delegation is the key to growth. I’ve seen firsthand how freeing up time from daily tasks can open up so many doors for innovation and strategy.

In my own business, one of the best things I’ve delegated is operations management. It’s helped me focus on bigger picture goals and serve my clients even better.

What’s the most surprising task you’ve delegated that had a big impact?
Moshe Rosenberg! Thanks for sharing! Giving over operations management is a huge step! Was a big turning point for me too.
truth!
The real hard truth Pery Weber  What was the first thing you delegated in your biz?

posts.name:
Nick Bilogorskiy 🇺🇦
Nick Bilogorskiy 🇺🇦
posts.content:
An incredible evening at the San Francisco premiere of Porcelain War - a Ukrainian documentary that captures the resilience of artists amid war.

Meeting Slava Leontyev and hearing him talk about the making of this film was deeply moving. Their story of creating beauty while defending their homeland is a testament to the human spirit. The documentary follows three artists - Slava, Anya, and Andrey - who use art and cameras as tools of resistance against the russian invasion.

Even under fighter jets and missile strikes, creativity cannot be destroyed. Slava’s porcelain art is a symbol of Ukraine's fragility and strength.

I was honored to speak at the opening of this Sundance Grand Jury Prize-winning documentary that shows how art can be an act of defiance and hope. 🇺🇦


See the film:

posts.name:
Krishna Kiran
Krishna Kiran
posts.content:
First principles thinking is cool and all. 

But here is Steve Jobs using analogies to time travel into the future with his mind, before the future was even possible.

He had mapped out app stores, saas and freemium in the 1980's by just thinking about radio stations.

Don't ditch Analogies because you call yourself a first-principles thinker.

Become able to use multiple thinking tools.

The quality of your thinking = the quality of the ideas you consume.
Follow along for more.

comments.commentText:
